title: 111_s1276
content: The "Private Fund Transparency Act of 2009" may be cited as the short title. The Act defines foreign private advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define a "foreign private adviser" as an investment adviser with no US office, fewer than 15 US clients, and less than $25,000,000 in assets under management from US clients. They do not publicly advertise as an investment adviser in the US. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines a "foreign private adviser" as an investment adviser with no US office, fewer than 15 US clients, and less than $25,000,000 in assets under management from US clients. They do not act as an investment adviser to any investment company registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940 or a business development company. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE ADVISERS. Section 203(b)(3) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include any investment adviser that is a foreign private adviser. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA; ANNUAL AND OTHER REPORTS. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to authorize the Commission to require registered investment advisers to maintain records and submit reports for the supervision of systemic risk by federal departments or agencies. Records of companies that would be investment companies but for certain exemptions, to which an investment adviser provides advice, are deemed to be the adviser's records. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to allow the Commission to require registered investment advisers to maintain records for the supervision of systemic risk. Records of companies advised by the investment adviser are considered the adviser's records. The Commission is not required to disclose supervisory reports filed under this provision. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to allow the Commission to request reports or information from registered investment advisers for regulatory purposes or court orders. This subsection is considered a statute under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended by eliminating Section 210 subsection (c) and clarifying rulemaking authority in Section 6. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to clarify rulemaking authority by allowing the Commission to define technical terms and classify persons and matters within its jurisdiction. Different requirements and meanings can be prescribed as necessary to achieve the purposes of the Act.
